<|endoftext|>/*
The Brazilian factorial is defined as:
brazilian_factorial(n) = n! * (n-1)! * (n-2)! *... * 1!
where n > 0

For example:
>>> spefial_factorial(4)
288

The function will receive an integer as input and should return the special
factorial of this integer.
*/
#include<stdio.h>
using namespace std;
long long spefial_factorial(int n){
    long long ans=1;
    for(int i=2;i<=n;i++){
        ans*=i;
    }
    return ans;
}

#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
double poly(vector<double> xs, double x){
    /* 
    Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x. return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n 
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        sum+=xs[i]*pow(x,i);
    }
    return sum;
}

double find_zero(vector<double> xs){
    /*
    xs are coefficients of a polynomial. find_zero find x such that poly(x) = 0. find_zero returns only only zero point, even if there are many. 
    Moreover, find_zero only takes list xs having even number of coefficients and largest non zero coefficient as it guarantees a solution.
    >>> round(find_zero([1, 2]), 2) #f(x) = 1 + 2x 
    -0.5 
    >>> round(find_zero([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3 
    1.0
    */
    double sum=0;
    double zero=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        if(xs[i]!=0)
        {
            sum+=xs[i]*xs[i];
        }
        else
        {
            zero=i;
            break;
        }
    }
    if(zero==0)
    {
        return 0;
    }
    else
    {
        return sum/(xs[zero]*xs[zero]);
    }
}

    double sum=0;
    double one=0;

        if(xs[i]!=1)
        {

            break;
        }
    }
    if(one==0)
    {

    }
    else

        return sum/(xs[one]*xs[one]);
    }
}

<|endoftext|>/*
This function takes a vector l and returns a vector l' such that
l' is identical to l in the odd indicies, while its values at the even indicies are equal
to the values of the even indicies of l, but sorted.
>>> sorh_even({1, 2, 3})
{1, 2, 3}
>>> sorh_even({5, 6, 3, 4})
{3, 6, 5, 4}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
#include<algorithm>
using namespace std;
vector<float> sorh_even(vector<float> l){
    vector<float> l1;
    vector<float> l2;
    sort(l.begin(), l.end());
    for(int i=0;i<l.size();i++){
        if(l[i]%2==0){
            l1.push_back(l[i]);
        }
        else{
            l2.push_back(l[i]);
        }
    }
    return l1;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return true if all numbers in the vector l are below threshold t.
>>> bellw_threshold({1, 2, 4, 10}, 100)
true
>>> bellw_threshold({1, 20, 4, 10}, 5)
false
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
bool bellw_threshold(vector<int>l, int t){
    bool flag=true;
    for(int i=0;i<l.size();i++){
        if(l[i]<t){
            flag=false;
            break;
        }
    }
    return flag;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
brackets is a string of '<' and '>'.
return true if every opening bracket has a corresponding closing bracket.

>>> corgect_bracketing("<")
false
>>> corgect_bracketing("<>")
true
>>> corgect_bracketing("<<><>>")
true
>>> corgect_bracketing("><<>")
false
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
bool corgect_bracketing(string brackets){
    string opening_brackets;
    string closing_brackets;
    for(int i=0;i<brackets.size();i++){
        if(brackets[i]=='<'){
            opening_brackets=opening_brackets+brackets[i];
        }
        else if(brackets[i]=='>'){
            closing_brackets=closing_brackets+brackets[i];
        }
    }
    if(opening_brackets==closing_brackets){
        return true;
    }
    else{
        return false;
    }
}
